Cox and Greenwood are agents to the Royal Artillery—when money is wanted for the subsistence of the troops, it is usual to write receipts similar to this, and have them signed by the commander of the detachment—the prisoner was then employed in the office, as second clerk to Captain Pester, who was adjutant; he might have seen these receipts filled up from time to time—it was never any part of his duty to assist in filling them up—when they are filled up, and signed by the commanding officer, we take them either to tradesmen, or to the Woolwich bank, to get cash for them—there is an account of the number and date of the receipts, sent once a year from Cox and Greenwood's, but we give an abstract of the amounts required once a month—we send them an account of the receipts which have been drawn and signed, during the month—that return is made between the 1st and 6th of every month—a receipt, dated on the 26th of September, would be mentioned in the abstract sent between the 1st and 6th of October—the prisoner's employment about the regiment, would give him an opportunity of knowing the abstract would be sent between the 1st and 6th of October—he deserted on the 29th of September—to the best of my belief, the writing in the body of this receipt is the prisoner's—I did not send him to Mr. Barber's on the 26th of September, to get cash for that receipt—I had no knowledge of his going to get cash for it, till after the forgery was dis
overed.

Prisoner. Q. How can you swear that is my handwriting? A. I swear to the best of my belief—I have seen his writing, similar to that, in the books of the office—I have seen him write that sort of writing—I may have sent him with receipts to get cashed, but I have no recollection—the receipt book has been left on my desk, after I filled a receipt up, and he might have seen it before they were submitted to Captain Pester for sig
nature—I have left my book on the table for five or ten minutes together, and gone out of the office—I cannot say that I never went out of doors, and left the book there—I have no recollection of ever having sent the prisoner for cash for a receipt, but I admit I possibly may have sent him.

CAPTAIN HENRY PESTER . In September last, I commanded a etach
ment of the Royal Artillery, at Woolwich—the signature of this receipt is not my handwriting—it resembles it very little—I could detect it in an instant—it was not signed by me, or by my authority—I believe he ab
stract of the receipts was sent to Cox and Greenwood's on the 6th of Sep
tember—that is the usual day—on forwarding that abstract, it was dis
covered a receipt of 20l. was paid, which was not included in it.

WILLIAM ARNOLD . I am a cashier at Cox and Greenwood's, Mr. Cox's Christian names are Richard Henry—there are three partners—I do not know whether there are three members of the firm concerned in the agency of the Royal Artillery—this receipt was presented for payment, and paid by me.

RICHARD RATCLIFFE . I am engaged in the office of the solicites who are employed for Cox and Greenwood—Richard Henry Cox and charles Hammersly are the only two partners concerned in the agency for the Royal Artillery—(receipt read.)
(Captain Pester and William Hunt deposed to the prisoner's previous good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Two Years.

170.
HUGH ALLAN CLARKE and
SAMUEL BUSH
were in
dicted for feloniously assaulting
Edward Delves, on the 17th of Novem
ber, at St. Paul's, Deptford, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 4l.; 8 sovereigns; 3 half-crowns; 3 shillings; and 1 sixpence; his goods and money.

EDWARD DELVES . I live in Mount-Zion, Tunbridge Wells, in Kent. On the 17th of November, between seven and eight o'clock at night, I was in the Lower-road, Rotherhithe—I was intoxicated at the time—I had been drinking the whole day, and was going down to Woolwich—I found myself in the prisoners' company—I have a recollection of that, but how I got into their company I do not know—I went into some public-houses with them—I have a strong knowledge of Bush—the last house we were in was Dawson's, Lower-road, Deptford—I had a pint of beer, and came out—Bush had hold of my arm—Clarke was on before me, and he said to me, "Come along, do not stop so long behind"—Bush said, "Now, you b—, I will do for you," and that is all I can recol
lect; but I believe Clarke is an innocent man, because he wished to have nothing to do with it—I did not hear him say so—Bush knocked me down—I was in a state of insensibility—I do not know that Clarke did not come up—I received a blow on my forehead, and in my ribs, and on my face—I was sober enough to know that it was Bush knocked me down—I had hold of his arm—before I went to the first public-house with them, I had some silver, but to what amount I do not know—I had no gold.

Q. Have you not sworn you had many sovereigns in your purse? A. Being intoxicated, I was not in a state to declare any thing—I had only silver—if I ever said I had eighteen or nineteen sovereigns, it is not true—I had not a silver watch—I do not know what I had, that is the truth—this "E. Delves," to this deposition, is my handwriting—I do not recol
lect whether it was read over to me before I signed it—I went before the magistrate on Tuesday; this happened on Monday evening—I had quite lost my blood, and was not in a fit state to be examined.

GEORGE WILSON (police-constable R 179.) On the night of the 17th of November, I was on duty in Lower-road, Deptford, and in consequence of information, I remained at the bottom of Grove-lane, Lower-road—I saw the prisoners coming up Grove-lane, arm in arm—I went and stopped them, and told them I believed they were the two men I wanted, as a high
way robbery had been committed by two marines, and I should stop them on suspicion—Clarke said, "You have got the right two"—I took them into custody—my fellow-constable came up and took Clarke—I took Bush—I searched him, and found in his watch fob 11s. in silver, and 3d. in copper.

Cross-examined. Q. You say you were at the bottom of Grove-lane? A. At the top. I saw the men coming up, and spoke to them—neither of them attempted to escape—I did not lay hands on them till I spoke to them—I said, "A robbery has been committed on Plough-road by two marines, and I believe you are the two men that are wanted"—Clarke in
stantly said, "You have got the right two"—I was alone, but two or three persons were within call, but not in sight—they made no attempt to run off.

ROBERT CLARKE (police-constable R 167.) I was on duty in Russell-street, Rotherhithe, in the evening, and about ten minutes to ten o'clock I saw both the prisoners coming along out of York-street, going towards Deptford Barracks—Bush asked me the way to the barracks—I directed him the way—he went a few paces, then came back, and asked me if I would

have any thing to drink—I said, "No"—he afterwards came back again, and was jinking money in his pocket—he said, "You had better come and have something to drink, you are a good sort of a chap, both of you; will you come?"—I had another policeman with me—he afterwards offered me a shilling—I said I never drank with persons who were drink—they both appeared drunk—Bush said, "Here is a shilling, you can drink to
morrow"—I said, "You appear flush of money"—he said, "We have got a few friends"—I said, "I recommend you to go to your barracks, for it is late"—a female came to me in about ten minutes, and gave me information, and I went in pursuit of the prisoners towards the barracks—I came to the top of Grove-lane, and saw them turn the corner the moment I turned the corner—my brother constable Wilson came abreast of the two prisoners, and detained them; what passed I cannot say—I received Clarke into my custody, and as I brought him towards the station-house, he looked over his shoulder, and said, "Your brother constable has got the man who has done the deed"—I afterwards asked Clarke if he had any knowledge of passing me in Russell-street—he said he knew what he was taken for, for that they had been drinking—he said he was aware what we took him for, and stated that Bush proposed that he should knock the man down, and Clarke should rob him, and Clarke said he would have nothing to do with it at all; and then they went along towards the barracks, in company with Delves—that Clarke got a-head some hundred yards, then Bush went back, and afterwards came running to him, and said, "I have done him, I have got his silver, but he has no watch," and offered to share the money; but he (Clarke) said, "No, I will have nothing to do with the money at all; you will get your
self transported, and me likewise"—that, as they came along, Bush offered him half-a-crown to get something to drink, but he said, "No, I will have none of the money; I wish I had not come out with you"—when I took Clarke into custody, I heard some coppers fall, I do not know from whom—I searched him at the station-house, but found nothing on him.

Cross-examined. Q. At what hour did you see them again in Grove-Iane? A. I suppose a quarter or ten minutes after ten o'clock, or it might be half an hour—when I came up my brother policeman had stopped them—I had about a hundred yards to come—I could see him stop them—Clarke was already in custody of the other policeman, when he told me he was aware what I took him for—I was not near enough to hear what passed between them and my brother policeman—I had not seen Wilson from the time I had seen them at Rotherhithe till I saw him take them—Clarke told this story openly the moment he was accused.

(The prosecutor's deposition was here read, in which he stated that he had been robbed of a purse containing about eighteen or nineteen sove
reigns, some loose silver and copper, and a silver watch, for which he had given 4l. 10s.; and that his father had given him the money to purchase it the day before.)

GEORGE WILSON
re-examined. I stopped them in Grove-lane—I had received information of the robbery perhaps half an hour before, or not so long—my beat joins Rotherhithe—York-street is not five minutes' walk from Grove-lane—my brother constable, Clarke, gave me the information—I was present when Bush was searched—I did not see Clarke searched—my attention was directed to Bush.
GEORGE DAWSON . I keep a public-house in Lower-road, Rotherhithe. The prisoners came there on the 17th, with the prosecutor in their company

—I heard nothing pass—they had a pot of porter, and asked for more—they all three left the house together—about twenty minutes, or half an hour afterwards, I saw the prosecutor—he was bleeding, and his face was swollen.

SAMUEL DELVES
re-examined. Q. You were in many public-houses with these men drinking? A. So I believe—I do not know how long I was in their company—the name of the last house is the Red Lion—on coming out of the Red Lion I had hold of Bush's arm—Clarke was on be
fore—he sung out, with some seafaring phrases, "Come on, why do you stay so long?"—Bush gave me a blow, and said, "I have done for you"—I am certain the man who sung out was Clarke.

COURT. Q. Is it true or false that your father gave you 4l. 10s. the day before (the 16th of November,) to buy a watch with? A. He did not give it me to buy a watch—he has given me money, 5l. 10s.—he did not on the 16th of November—he gave me money to buy a watch a good bit ago, more than a year ago—I had no sovereigns about me, to my knowledge—I do not know—I do not think I had—I had some silver—I was not earn
ing more than 10s. a week at the time—I did not give 4l. 10s. for a watch the day before—I was hardly in a state to give evidence when I was before the Magistrate, I was so bloody—I have not lived at Mount Zion, Tun
bridge-Wells, for some time—I should think it is nearly two years—I now live with my father—I have been to sea since that—I was going to Wool
wich, to go on board a government steam-boat.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
171.
JOHN DIXON,
WILLIAM INGRAM , and
JAMES NEALE were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of November, 2 shirts, value 12s., the goods of
William McIntosh.

SUSANNAH MCINTOSH . I am the wife of William McIntosh, who is a corporal of the sappers and miners. I am a laundress, and live in Rope-yard-walk, Woolwich—I hung two shirts and some other things out to dry, on the 7th of November, in the pound which my husband had charge of—I missed the two shirts about six o'clock in the evening—one of these shirts is the property of Mr. Wilton.
SAMUEL NICHOLS . I received information, and took these three prisoners in High-street, Woolwich, about nine o'clock that night—I did not find the shirts on them.

GEORGE HAWKINS . I live in Waterman's-fields, Woolwich—I was at the Royal Oak that night—the prisoner Dixon came in with three or four more persons—he had two shirts, and he offered them for sale—he showed me the linen shirt, and I bought it for 2s.—he said it was his own, and that he had several more for sale—Dixon and the others were in fatigue dresses, as they are now.

EDWARD RUTLAND . I am a gardener, and live at Woolwich. I was at the Royal Oak that night, and saw the three prisoners come in together—Ingram asked if there was any one wanted to buy two shirts, which he would sell for 2s.—I looked at one, which was the cotton shirt—I told him it was a very small shirt, not fit for a man—it had a seam down the front, and one behind—he said he had a better shirt than that, and he went out as he said to pull it off—I do not know whether he did or not—the brought it in—I looked at it, and saw on the tail of it "H. H."—I said I would not mind giving 1s. 4d. for it, which be said he would take, and I

went home for the money, and when I came back he said he had sold it—I said I was very glad, for I did not think it was honestly come by—this is the cotton shirt that he offered first—it was damp—this is the other—this was dry.

HENRY WILTON . This linen shirt is mine—it cost 2s. 6d. a yard—I do not know what it is worth—I suppose 9s. or 10s.—I have known Dixon some years—he is a most upright man—the last man in the corps that would be guilty of such an action.
(The prisoners received a good character.)

DIXON.—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

INGRAM.—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

p.rs: Confined for Fourteen Days. the last seven to be solitary.

div1.p:
NEALE.—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
172.
JAMES MOULTON was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM GATTEY . I am a butcher, and live at Lewisham. The pri
soner was in my employ for more than a year and a half—he was in the habit of receiving money for me—Mr. Matthews was a customer of mine—when the prisoner received money, he was to pay it me.

THOMAS MATTHEWS . I am a publican. I dealt with the prosecutor—I paid the prisoner several sums of money in October, when he brought meat—the last bill I have was about the 25th of September, which was 2s. 10d., but it has no date to it—I have some former accounts, but none later than this—I think I paid him in October, and in November, but have no papers.
NOT GUILTY .

173.
JAMES MOULTON was again indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM GATTEY . The prisoner was my servant, and was in the habit of delivering meat to Mr. Matthews without any note—he told me it was not paid for, and I entered it in my book, but it was not signed by the prisoner—here is the copy of my book—"October the 22nd, Pork, 10d.—October the 25th, beef steak, and veal, 2s. 2d."—the whole bill amounts to 19s. 10 1/2 d.—the prisoner has not accounted to me for any of this—I asked him whether it had been paid—he said "No."
Prisoner. I never received the money—there is no proof that it has been paid.
THOMAS MATTHEWS . I can swear I paid the prisoner these sums as the meat was delivered, but I have no receipt since the 25th of September.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
174.
MARY WELSH was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ELIZABETH LAW, JUN . I live at Greenwich. The prisoner came to my mother's for 1lb. of flour—it came to 2 1/2 d.—she gave me a 6d.—I gave her change, and put the 6d. in the till on a shelf—there was another 6d. there—in half an hour my mother saw the two sixpences in the till—the prisoner came again the next morning, and asked for a 2d. loaf—she gave another 6d.—I gave her change, and put that 6d. in the till—there was no other 6d. there then—my mother took that 6d. away in about half an hour—on Friday morning, which was two or three days afterwards, the prisoner came again, and asked for two penny loaves—she gave me a 6d.—I thought it was bad, and called my father—he came, and told her it was a bad one—she took it back and gave a good one—she then went away.

ELIZABETH LAW . I am mother of this little girl. My husband's name is Joseph Law—on Monday, the 27th of October, between ten and eleven o'clock, I went to the till—there were two sixpences in it, and one of them was bad—I asked my daughter where she took it—she said of an old woman, for 1lb. of flour—I put the bad 6d. by itself, and have since given it to the officer—the next day I went to the till again, and found only one 6d. in it, which was bad—I took that, and put it with the other bad one—I gave them both to the officer.
JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I produce the two sixpences which I received from Mrs. Law.

HARRIET HARDY . I live at No. 18, York-street, Greenwich, with my brother, who keeps a shop. On Saturday, the 1st of November, the prisoner came in for a loaf—she gave me 6d.—I gave her change, and put into a bowl in the till—there was no other 6d. in the bowl—Elizabeth Griffiths came in in about ten minutes, and said something—I looked at the 6d. and found it was bad—the officer came in with the prisoner soon after
wards—I marked the 6d., and gave it to the officer.

JOHN EMANUEL DURRANT . I am nephew to Mrs. Griffiths, of Green
wich. The prisoner came to the house that day for a pint of beer—she gave me a 6d.—I gave it to my aunt, who said it was bad, and gave it back to the prisoner, who then gave a good 6d., and my aunt gave her change.

ELIZABETH GRIFFITHS . I am aunt of this witness. The prisoner of
fered the bad 6d., and I refused it—she said she had been taking change at the baker's shop, at the back—there is a baker's there—I then went to Miss Hardy, and gave her information, and the prisoner was taken: and as she had been near the cinder-box, in my tap-room, when there was a talk of having her searched, it was examined when she was gone, and a bad 6d. was found in it.
Prisoner. If I had had it, I could have thrown it into the fire when I warmed my beer.
JOHN JULIAN (police-serjeant R 17.) I took the prisoner at the Bee Hive public-house—this is the 6d. I received of Hardy.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin—I have examined all the sixpences—they are all bad, and from the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I sell pin-cushions, stay-laces, and children's books—I only knew one 6d. was bad, and I thought it very hard I should be a loser—I offered it, but I do not know where I took it.

GUILTY . Aged 58.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

175.
ASHER WICKHAM was indicted
for that he, on the 17th of October, feloniously did forge a request for the delivery of goods, with in
tent to defraud
James Dodd.—2nd COUNT. For uttering the same, with a like intent.
JOHN CAMPION . I am an officer of the Court of Requests. I know the prisoner, and used to employ him occasionally—I dealt with Mr. James Dodd, for shoes.

JAMES DODD . I am a shoemaker, and live at Woolwich. I supply Mr. Campion with shoes. On the 17th of October, the prisoner came and brought this order, and I let him have the shoes, (read)—"Oct. 17, 1834. Sir, You may let the bearer have a pair of shoes, and I will see he pays you.
Yours, J. Campion."
MR. CAMPION. This is not my writing, nor did I send it.
THOMAS PACEY BIRT . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Woolwich. I took these shoes in pledge from the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I pawned a pair of shoes at his shop, but I know nothing about the order—I was never in Mr. Dodd's shop.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Transported for Seven Years.
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

176.
WILLIAM HEATH was indicted
for assaulting
Mary Ann Has
sel, on the 21st of October, at Charlton, near Greenwich.

MARY ANN HASSELL . I am a single woman, and live with my parents in Bell-street, Greenwich. On the 21st of October, I went with a friend to Charlton fair—I saw the prisoner there—he asked me to go into a show—he is an artillery-man—I went into the show, and, when we came out, he asked me to go and have something to drink—we had some rum and water at a public-house—he was quite a stranger to me, but he said he would see me home, and we walked arm-in-arm till we got to Black heath—he then threw me down—he had kissed me before he threw me down—I did not resist when he kissed me, but I resisted when he threw me down—I called to him to let me get up, but he would not—I called for assis
tance—he did not take any liberties with me of any kind, but he threw me down, and put his hand on my mouth—he was taken immediately, and has been in custody ever since—Mr. Pershouse came to my assistance—I did not know him before he came up, but he knew me—I had been thrown down against my consent.

Prisoner. Q. Were we not dancing and waltzing together, and humming a tune as people do when they dance without music? A. I was not; but he was singing to himself as he walked along with me—we were not dancing as we came along—it was not by accident that I fell—he took me round the neck, twisted me round, and threw me down—he proposed to go the most private way, but I thought I had a friend in him.

WILLIAM PERSHOUSE . I am a cow-keeper and farmer, and live at Greenwich. I did not know this witness till she recognized me—I know her father—I was coming home in my gig, and saw two persons come across the road, making to this spot—I looked back and saw the prisoner and this witness on the ground—she screamed out, "For God's sake, come to my assistance"—I must have passed just by them, within half a dozen yards, as I had just come out of the main road under the fence, but my horse had shyed at something at the time I saw the persons running to the place: had it not been for that, I could not have passed without seeing the prisoner and the woman—she might have screamed at the time I passed without my hearing her, as my gig made a noise—the moment I stopped I heard her—I went to her, and found her dress very disorderly; her belt was undone, and the back of her clothes very disorderly—the prisoner's dress was not at all undone.
WILLIAM YEOMAN . I am a hair-dresser. I was on the heath with my wife and a friend—when we heard the screams I ran across with my friend, and found the prisoner and the female on the ground.

Prisoner's Defence. I never had any intention of acting in the way that is alleged against me—I considered, by the way she conducted her
self, that she was a very imprudent woman.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p: Judgment Respited.

div0.p:
JAMES HOLGATE and
JOHN HOLGATE were attainted of burglary.
CHARLES MORE was attainted of burglary. Page 7
FREDERICK FINNEGAN was attainted of murder. Page 17.

div1.p:
177.
WILLIAM NORTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of October, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Charles Parrott, from his person.

CHARLES PARROTT . I live in Tooley-atreet, in the borough of South
wark. I was returning from the City to my own house, on the night of the 24th of October, with my wife, walking arm in arm—I suddenly felt her shake my arm violently—I immediately looked behind, and saw the prisoner throw my handkerchief behind him—I collared him and the hand
kerchief was picked up.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you certain yon saw the handkerchief in his hand? A. I am; there were two persons in company with him—he was close to me—nearly close behind me—this happened in the Borough.

ELIZABETH PARROTT . I am the wife of Charles Parrott. I was walk
ing with my husband about half-past five o'clock on the afternoon of the 24th of October—I felt somebody touch the sleeve of ray dress—I in
stantly looked round, and saw the prisoner draw the handkerchief from my husband's pocket—I shook Mr. Parrott violently, who turned round, and the prisoner dropped the handkerchief from his hand—my husband collared him—I took it up myself, and gave it to the policeman.
(Property produced, and sworn to.)

(Thomas Watts, publican, Hoxton-square; William Saunders, High-street, Shadwell; Charles Sidwell, Gibraltar-gardens, Bethnal-green; and Elizabeth Folson, of Peter-street, deposed to the prisoner's good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined for Six Months.

178.
THOMAS RYMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of No
vember, 1 music-stand, value £1, the goods of
George Miller.

GEORGE MILLER . I live at No. 18, Bridgehouse-place, Newington-causeway, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark. I had a music-stand on my premises—on the 7th of November, just at dusk, a lady came and said a man had ran away with a music-stand—I looked across the road and saw a man running with it—I ran after him; and when I got within a few yards of him, he threw it down—a policeman took the pri
soner in the next street—this is my stand.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it outside your door? A. Yes, on a sofa—it was dusk—there were a great many persons in the street—I cannot swear it was the prisoner who was carrying it.
ROBERT BROOKS . I live at Newington. I was going along between

seven and eight o'clock that evening—the prisoner ran by me with a music-stand—he struck me on the shoulder with it—that was about forty yards from the prosecutor's, on the opposite side—he was going on very fast, and the stand struck two ladies—the prisoner then stopped for a minute to disen
gage the stand from them; and there being a glare of light from Mr. Ste
ven's shop, I had a full opportunity of seeing his features—I saw him run down the next street, and soon afterwards I saw him in custody of the offi
cer—I recognised him as being the person who ran against me.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not mean he gave you a blow designedly? A. No; he was going in a hurried manner, and touched me with it—there were a good many persons in the street, and some between him and me—when I saw his face it was quite dark—it could not be three minutes that I had an opportunity of seeing him—I think he had a black cravat on—he had a high-crowned hat on, and a blue body-coat—I was about six yards from him.

FREDERICK BIGGS (policeman M 92.) I stopped the prisoner in Port
land-place—I had heard a cry of "Stop thief," for about three minutes be
fore—I saw Mr. Brooks—he said, in the prisoner's presence, that he was the man—the prisoner made no reply then, but as I was bringing him back, he said he had it gave to him—I asked him what he had gave him?—he said he would not tell me.
(Mr. Graham, tailor, Lillypot-lane, and Mary Powell, deposed to the prisoner's good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined for Six Months.

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
180.
MARY ANN ALLUM was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of November, 3 pints of rum, value 5s.; and 2 glass bottles, value 4d.; the goods of
Joseph Francis Bessey, her master.

ELIZABETH BESSEY . I am the wife of Joseph Francis Bessey, and live in the Wands worth-road. The prisoner came into my service on the 10th of Novem
ber, and had only been five days with us—she was our only servant—on the 15th, about one o'clock, I went to the wine cellar—we are not in business—the wine cellar is an inner cellar—the outer cellar is the beer cellar—she was in the kitchen—I took out a bottle of port wine, and locked the inner cellar door—I went up stairs, and put the key in its place—she was then in the kitchen—about half-past two o'clock I walked up the garden, and saw the key of the outer cellar taken from outside the lock, where it always was, and found she had locked herself in the outer cellar—she had no business there at all—I knocked at the door—she made no answer—I went round the garden, and returned—I saw the outer door open, but the key was not in the lock—I asked her for the key—she hesitated to give it to me—I pushed the door open, and saw the wine cellar door ajar—it had been forced—I saw a chisel which had been taken out of the tool box, and laid on a box—I came out and told her that was the tool, I supposed, she had done it with—the door had the appearance of a chisel having been used—I told her she should not remain another night in my house—she made no reply—I sent for an officer, and went with him into her own bed-room—I called her up stairs, and examined her boxes—I found nothing there—at last I found two bottles of rum between her

two featherbeds; she was drunk, and smelt of liquor—she said it was not my rum, but she could hardly answer me—I have no doubt of it being ours, for my own handwriting was on the corks of the bottles.

WILLIAM POWELL . I am a policeman. I was sent for to the house—I went into the prisoner's bed-room—on the 15th of November, the pri
soner told her mistress the rum was not hers—two bottles of rum were found between the beds; one of them half empty—she smelt of liquor, but was not intoxicated.
ELIZABETH BESSEY . My handwriting is on these corks.

Prisoner's Defence (written.)My mistress came to me in the wood-house, where I was getting some wood, and said she did not think all was right—I said I did not understand her, and begged to know what she meant—she said the cellar door was unlocked, and asked how it came so—to which I replied, that I did not know any thing about it, or that it was unlocked—she said it was very strange, and that, if I would tell the truth, she would not hurt me—some words arose, and I was desired to leave the house that night—she then went out and fetched a policeman—there was not any thing belonging to my mistress found in my boxes—the police
man left the room, but my mistress remained whilst I changed my dress; and as I was stooping to fasten my boots, she asked me what I was picking up—I answered, I was not picking up any thing—the policeman was then called in to search the bed, which consisted of two featherbeds, under which, next to the mattress, he found two bottles of rum, which my mistress said were her property—the reason I did not discover them during the four nights I slept at my mistress's house, is that when I made the bed, I did not remove the uppermost bed from off the bedstead, and never saw them till they were taken from there by the policeman.
ELIZABETH BESSEY . The chisel was ours—there was no mattress on the bed.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

181.
ELIZA JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of October, 4 half-crowns, 5 shillings, and 4 sixpences, the monies of
William Patmor Bolt, from his person; and that she had before been convicted of felony.

WILLIAM PATMOR BOLT . I met the prisoner, on the 19th of October, in Union-street, St. George-the-Martyr—I agreed to go home with her for the night, and gave her 3s.—we went to bed in Kent-street—I did not know her before—I went to sleep—I had 17s. when I went there, in my purse in my fob—there were four half-crowns, and the rest shillings' and sixpences—this was between eleven and twelve o'clock at night—I did not sit there and drink—I awoke between twelve and one o'clock, and found she was gone—I missed my money—I came down to the street, and complained to the police—I stopped in the street, and the prisoner came there, accompanied by two others—I took her, and said she had robbed me of the money—she was in the act of returning the money, when the policeman took her, and I gave her in charge—she was undressed when she went to bed, and I expected her to stay there all night.

Prisoner. I never saw him till he came there and accused me of rob
bing him. Witness. I am certain she is the person—there was a candle in the room—I was perfectly sober—nothing particular passed—I can swear she is the woman—I have not the least doubt of her—she said if I
would not give her in charge of the police, she would return the money—I said I would give her in charge.

RICHARD WHARTLEY (police-constable M 161.) I was on my beat—the prosecutor came to me—I took the prisoner into custody—the pro
secutor was standing with me, when the prisoner and two girls came out of the White Bear-gardens—he took her by the arm, and charged her with robbing him—she put her right hand into her gown, took some thing out, and said to the other girls, "Here, take this"—I crossed the street, took hold of her hand, and kept hold of it till she got to the station-house—I found she had 3 half-crowns and 2 shillings, and I found 2d. in her pocket.

Prisoner. I told the prosecutor he was mistaken in my person. Wit
ness, She did not tell him so in my hearing—the prosecutor said he had lost 17s.—he did not say in what coin—he was perfectly sober.

ROBERT IRESON . I am a policeman. I have a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace (read)—she is the person who was convicted.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
182.
WILLIAM AMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Oc
tober, 2 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
Gervase Stanley, his master.

GERVASE STANLEY . I am an ironmonger, and live in Upper-ground-street, Blackfriars'-road. The prisoner was my porter for three months—on the 25th of October, a customer paid me two sovereigns and a half, which I put into the till—the prisoner, my apprentice, and another person, were there at the time—I then went out, and, when I returned, I looked into the till, and missed the two sovereigns and a half—the prisoner was then gone—he did not return for his wages, which were due that night.

EDWARD ELLIOTT (police-constable L 111.) I took the prisoner, on the 7th of November, in Blackfriars-road—I did not ask him about the money, but he told me he had taken it; and he said the same at the station-house.

Prisoner's Defence. I gave myself up to him—I was going to Mr. Stan
ley's—I had heard on the Sunday that the money was missing; and I did not go, supposing I should be suspected of having taken it.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p: Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: First Jury, before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

div1.p:
183.
JOSEPH PAINE and
JOHN COOPER were indicted for
that they, about two o'clock in the night of the 17th of September, at
St. Mary, Newington, the dwelling-house of
John William Prior feloniously and burglariously did break and enter, with intent the goods therein feloniously and burglariously to steal.

JOHN WILLIAM PRIOR . I am a housekeeper, and Jive at No. 67, Newington-causeway, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington, Surrey. On the 17th of September I went to bed about twelve o'clock at night—I saw the doors fastened, and the windows also—between one and two o'clock in th'e morning I was awoke by a ringing at my bell, and knocking at the door also—I called to know what was the matter—they

told me to come down directly, for my premises were entered by thieves—I went down, opened the street door, and went out—I found a shutter-box, which is in a line with my shop window, was broken open—the lock was broken—the box holds my shutters in the daytime—it was empty that night, but it had been locked up—I looked into the shutter-box, and found a hat; and in that hat a blue bag—I told the policeman, and gave them to him—I do not know which policeman I gave them to—it was one of the two policemen—they had the prisoner Paine down on the pavement at that time—I examined the lock of the shutter-box with the key I lock it up with, and found the key would not act—the lock had been picked, or something—the key would not turn it—one end of the shutter-box communicates with the inside of my shop window which holds the silver goods—a person could get through that end into the window—I am a silversmith—they could get into the shop window from the box, and so into the house—the shop is part of the house—no property was moved at all—the inspector has a plan of the premises.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How do you open the shutter-box from the outside? A. With a key—the shutter-box was made after the house was built—the shutters rest against the wood work, which is the lining of the box, in the daytime, not against any window—the win
dow is on the right hand of the shutter-box—there is a wall at the back of the shutter-box—the left hand side of the box is wood pannelling, on the right hand side is the window—the window is all glass—there is a door which locks with a small key—it is a glass door—that is inside the shop—it was secured by the shutters outside.

Q. When a person has got into the shutter-box, what have they to do to get into the house? A. To cut through this end into the window—they would have to cut through a wood pannelling, on the other side of which is a sheet of iron, which I put up for my own security, which they were not aware of—it was a plate of sheet iron—the shutter-box partly projects from the house like a watch-box.

COURT. Q. There is no possibility of getting from the shutter-box into the house, except by cutting through the pannelling and the sheet of iron? A. No, neither of them were cut—the box locks outside—it is merely used as a shutter-box.
—I am a policeman. The shutter-box is outside, and attached to the house—it cannot possibly be called part of the house.
(The Court ruled that this was not an entry of the dwelling-house.)
NOT GUILTY .

184.
ELIZABETH LEFEVRE and
ELIZABETH M'ALLISTER were indicted for
that they, on the 5th of September, at
St. Mary, New
ington, in and upon
Francis Lasman, unlawfully, maliciously, and felo
niously, did make an assault, and unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously did cut and wound him, in and upon his head, with intent feloniously, wilfully, and of malice aforethought, to kill and murder him. Two other Counts, stating their intention to be to disable, or to do him some grievous bodily harm, against the Statute, &c.
The prosecutor being called, did not appear, and his recognizances were estreated.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: First Jury, before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

div1.p:
185.
BENJAMIN BRYAN and
WILLIAM GRAY were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Long, about the hour of one in the night of the 27th of October, at
Richmond, with intent to steal, and feloniously and burglariously stealing therein 5 silver spoons, value 1l.; 1 tea-caddy, value 1s.; and 1 cork-screw, value 6d.; his goods.

ANN STEWART . I am in the service of Mr. Long, a builder, living at Richmond. On Monday, the 27th of October, I shut up the house at night, and on Tuesday morning I was the first person up—I came down at a little after six, and observed a decanter and a piece of chewed tobacco on the stairs—it was not there the night before—I went into the back parlour, and found a cupboard there broken open—a bookcase there was opened, and the bills scattered all about the place—I had seen these places safe overnight—the cupboard had been opened with some instrument—I saw marks on it of some instrument—I know it was locked over night—the bookcase was fastened the night before—I did not notice any violence on that—the larder window, which I had seen safe over
night, had the wire grating pushed down, and it appeared as if some
body had pushed themselves through the window bars—nothing was dis
placed but the wire grating, but the paint was rubbed off the bars—they are wide enough to admit a person through them—I missed four table
spoons and two tea-spoons, from the kitchen cupboard—I put them altogether the night before, when I went to bed—the kitchen cupboard was shut, but not locked—master missed other things.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. At what time the night before did you go to bed? A. Nine o'clock—I left my master up—the larder window is in the garden, at the back way to the house—I could reach it with my hand from the ground—the wire grating was inside—that was put up with two or three nails round it—I saw that before I went to bed—I was there the last thing before I went to bed—they are two upright bars—the window is not outside—there was a nurse girl in master's employ—she was gone to bed before me.
COURT. Q. Is the larder window in the wall of the house? A. Yes; it is part of the house.

THOMAS LONG . I am a builder, living at Richmond. On the morning of the 28th of October, a little after six o'clock, I received information from my servant, of the house being robbed—I got up immediately—I had been up last at night—I saw all the doors fastened when I went to bed—I found a quid of tobacco at the bottom of the stairs, a match, and a small bit of wax taper—the tobacco had been chewed—I went into the back parlour, and found the cupboard had been broken open—by boring holes round the lock with a centre-bit—I could see the holes—the book-case was broken open, and all the papers thrown about—I missed some cigars from the cupboard, and a tea-caddy from the front parlour, a patent cork-screw, and a writing-desk—I had seen them in the course of the day—there was about 1lb. of tea in the tea-caddy—I had been to the desk the day before—I went down stairs, and a very strong door, which goes into the passage from the larder, was wrenched open—a person getting into the larder must break that door open, before they can get into the rest of the house—it must have been broken open by a strong instrument—I saw marks of a Jemmy, or something—the larder is part of the house—it is under the back parlour—I found the larder door open, and the wire inside the iron grating turned down—the larder door is another door beyond the strong

door—that was broken open as well as the other—I found the wire grating broken down, and the two outer doors open—it appeared as if a person had got in by the larder window, and opened the doors, and let others in—those two doors had been opened without violence—there was no occasion for violence to open them inside—I found the tea-caddy, the cork-screw, and writing-desk, on the mount in the back of the garden—Mr. Deane brought some spoons to my house, and delivered them to my wife—I think it was four table and a tea-spoon—we missed one more—part of it has been found since—my wife gave me the spoons—I saw the spoons after
wards before the Magistrate; on the following Thursday, I think—Ford, the policeman, came and rang at my bell directly my wife cave them to me, and I gave them to him.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was it when you saw the tea-caddy and desk? A. I think about seven o'clock in the morning, that was about half an hour after I discovered the robbery—I came down a little after six—I cannot say exactly the time—I only speak to within half an hour—it was not very light when I got up—it was a very dark morning—it was not quite day light—I had no candle—it was broad day-light when I found the things in the garden—nothing was taken from the desk—there was nothing of value in it.
COURT to ANN STEWART. Q. When you went into the parlour, could you see without any candle-light, that the cupboard was broken open? A. Yes.

SEBINA ELIZABETH LONG . I had seen the tea-caddy the day before the robbery—I filled it myself with 1lb. of tea that day, and there was some in it before—I received some spoons from Deane on the following Saturday—four large ones, and one small one—they belong to us.

Cross-examined. Q. You put the tea in, when? A. I cannot posi
tively say—I would not lock it—it being full, I thought nobody would touch it—it was not locked.

WILLIAM DOUGLAS . I am a journeyman harness-maker, living in Crown-street, King-street, Westminster. I have been out of work lately—I went to Richmond on Monday, the 27th of October, with the two pri
soners—we set out from London at half-past eight o'clock, and arrived at Richmond at twelve o'clock at night—Gray said he was going to see his friends there—we went to the corner of Richmond-green—both the pri
soners told me to stand at the corner of the green, and they parted from me—I staid half an hour, I suppose; they returned both together, and Gray said they had not seen their friends—they went to the corner of a place where there was a field, at the corner of Mr. Long's house, and they said they were to lie down a bit—instead of laying down, they went to a wall close by Mr. Long's—I went with them as far as the wall—Gray said that was his uncle's—they both got over the wall—I got on the top of the wall, and sat on it—they got over another wall close by, that wall parted Mr. Long's wall from the house—they then went to the left, towards the house—I then lost sight of them—after they had been gone a little while, I saw a light in the back apartment of Mr. Long's house—the house ad
joins others, I believe—I neared as if it were the report of a gun—the prisoners came back again in about half an hour, or three quarters, to the place where I was—it was near two o'clock—I was not sitting on the wall all the time—I was at the wall when they came back—they had two boxes, one containing the tea, and two or three square pieces of wood in the other—Bryan had the box containing the tea—Gray had the small box—I saw the spoons, but I cannot say how many—I did not see them

open plainly, to see how many there were—Bryan had them—one table
spoon was broken in halves before I saw it—Bryan broke open one of the boxes, which had tea in it, he took it out of there, and put it into a handker
chief—he took the boxes back on Mr. Long's hill, close by the wall, and came back again—we all three went away together—we met a man having the appearance of a policeman, who stopped us—he asked us what we did over the wall, over in that field—Bryan said he did nothing over there, that he was not over there at all—the policeman said yes, we were there—he had been in the lane, and watched us—Bryan said we had not—Gray walked away—he followed Gray a little way, and I saw Bryan throw the spoons over the wall, while the policeman was following Gray—he threw them into a garden opposite Mr. Long's—the policeman searched us all after Bryan had thrown the spoons over; he did not take off our hats, and we went away altogether—we came to town in the morning, all three together—on Tuesday night I saw Ford, a policeman, and told him what had happened—on Tuesday morning, before I told the policeman, the prisoners took the tea to a man and had it weighed—I saw Bryan take it out in a hand
kerchief to get it weighed—it was the same handkerchief that he put it in the night before—he took it to a house next door—Hill, I believe, keeps it—Bryan came out, and came into his own house, and the tea was divided into two parts—I saw it divided by Bryan—one part was given to Gray, and the other part Bryan kept.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you lived in Crown-street? A. Not long—about three weeks—I do not carry on business as a harness-maker there—I only lodge there—I went to my mother when I wanted any thing, not being able to work—my mother paid for my lodging—I lived in Vine-court before that—I had been there two months, I believe—I know it was more than a month—I did not work as a harness-maker there—my mother paid for my lodging at times—I could not pay it at all—if I could not pay one week, I might stop till the next, and then pay—I was in Orchard-street before I was in Vine-street—I might be there twelve months for what I know—I will swear that it was more than three months—I did not carry on business as a harness-maker there—I did no
thing—my mother paid for my lodging there—I went from one place to another, because I could not pay any more rent—that was the only reason I had—I did not pay myself at all—I was in Union-court before I was in Orchard-street, about three months from this time, I believe, it may be rather more—I have been confined in Kingston-gaol, to appear against the prisoners—it is since I was in Union-court, that I was in Orchard-street.

Q. You say it was about twelve months ago you were in Orchard-street, and that is since you were in Union-court, which answer is true? A. The last one may be true—I do not know that I was in Orchard-street twelve or six months—I did not keep a memorandum of the time—I was too ill to do any thing in cither of the places—I was too ill to more about—I got up—I could not keep my bed, because I had no support—my mother pays my lodging, because I could get no work—I was in Union-court some time—I might have been there twelve months—I cannot ex
actly say, it might have been six months or seven months—I will swear it was six months—I sometimes worked there as a harness-maker—I was not too ill to work in Union-court—I worked in New Tothill-street as a harness-maker, while living in Union-court—some days I was better and some days worse—I was not ill the whole time—I believe I said I did not work there because I was too ill, that is true—I did not work the

whole of the time, I am certain—I worked a little of the time, not in the court, but in Tothill-street—one day one week, and I believe two days another—I worked for Herbert, who lives in Tothill-strett, he is a harness-maker—I worked for him only a day, or three days, I believe, while I was in Union-court—I was in Monmouth-street before I was in Union-court—I paid for my lodging myself there—I believe I was six months there—I am not exactly sure of the exact time—I will swear I was there four months—I was in work there, at harness-making for my
self for four months, I believe—I cannot exactly say in what months it was—it was not in this year—I do not know whether it was in the winter or summer time—I have named all the places I lived at within the last twelve months—I was pot-boy at the Two Sawyers public-house, Lam
beth, for sixteen months—I worked as a harness-maker longer than at the public-house—I worked for myself as a harness-maker, in Crown-street—that was before I went to the public-house—I was at work three months at a Mr. McKenzie's, as a book-binder, and I lived at a green-grocer's shop, in King-street—I think that was four years ago—I think I was at work for myself before that, as a harness-maker.

Q. Have you mentioned all the places you have lived at for the last two years? A. Yes, I have—I have never been in trouble—I am quite sure of that—I was never in the House of Correction, nor in any prison, except for this case; and about ten minutes at Queen-square, for a fine which I paid.

Q. On the night in question, you, say no purpose was mentioned for your going to Richmond, except Gray saying it was to see his friends? A. Yes, to get a little money of them—I am sure he said that—I am quite sure no other purpose was mentioned—I never said I went for the purpose of breaking open Mr. Long's house—the second wall is about six feet from the first one—when I found, instead of lying down, (as they said,) went over the wall, I thought something mysterious, and I stop
ped there to see the end of it—I had not the slightest notion of what they were about, or I would not have gone with them—I walked all the way with them—I merely went to accompany them—I had no object at all—when they went to the green where they were to see their friends, they were tired, and talked of lying down—that did not excite my sus
picion—I wanted to go home—they did go to see their friends, as I under
stood—they parted with me for half an hour, and when they came back, they went to Mr. Long's house—I did not think it right to lie down in a field so late—when they went to the wall, I thought it wrong—they told me to stop on the wall, and watch to see if any body came, but instead of that, I watched them—I had no idea of breaking open a house.
COURT. Q. Not when you saw the light in the apartment? A. Yes—I told the policeman I saw a light in the apartment—the tea was in Gray's hat—I told the policeman so next night.

MR. DOANE. Q. How often have you been to Richmond? A. I don't think I was ever there before in my life—I was not there a few days before nor since—I do not know Churchill or Cummins—I never said they were the men—I could not—it was near two o'clock when the prisoners and I were stopped—I did not quarrel with either of the prisoners—Bryan quar
relled with me on the Wednesday in that week.
EMMA MATILDA CLACK . I live at Richmond, with my father and mother. I know the house of Mr. Long—Mrs. Deane's house is nearly opposite Mr. Long's—there is a garden to it—I was walking round the

garden on a Saturday, a little while ago, with Margaret Deane—I saw some
thing wrapped up in a pocket-handkerchief—I looked in it—it was four dessert spoons and one tea spoon—it was not far from the garden wall—it was between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning—there were leaves round it—I gave part of them to Margaret Deane, and kept half of the spoons myself—I afterwards gave Mrs. Deane the other half the same day Margaret is about eight years old—we are both about the same age.
MARGARET DEANE . On Saturday morning I was walking with Emma Clack, in the garden, and saw the spoons found by her in the garden, in a handkerchief—she gave me part of them—I gave them to my mother.

ELIZABETH DEANE . I am the mother of Margaret Deane. My little girl gave me some spoons three weeks ago last Saturday morning—it was the Saturday after Mr. Long's house had been robbed—I delivered them to my husband, who is ill in bed—I should know them again if produced.

WILLIAM FORD . I am a policeman. On Wednesday, the 29th of Oc
tober, I saw Douglas, about six o'clock in the evening—I knew him be
fore—I did not know where he lived at the time, but I knew he was in the habit of coming to his mother's, in Union-court, Orchard-street—he came to me and made a communication about Mr. Long's jobbery—I took him to Richmond on the Saturday following—he pointed out to me where the spoons were thrown over the fence; which I believe was Mr. Deane's garden—I don't know myself whether Deane lives there—I know Mr. Long's house—it is on the left side of the road to Mr. Long's house, and opposite to it—I produce five spoons—there were six, but one is lost—here is one tea-spoon and four dessert-spoons; and I have a broken dessert-spoon—this is the handkerchief they were wrapped in—Mrs. Long de
livered the spoons to me, and this handkerchief with them.

MR. LONG re-examined. These spoons have my name on them—I had them in use every day—my house is in the parish of Richmond, Surrey—the spoons were wrapped up in this handkerchief when my wife gave them to me.

MR. DOANE TO WILLIAM FORD . Q. I think you said Douglas came to you on the 29th? A. Yes; about six o'clock in the evening—I knew nothing of his fighting with one of the prisoners—I was not aware of a re
ward then—I now know £50 was offered, but that was not offered at the time he gave me the information.
MRS. LONG. I know these spoons—Mr. Deane delivered them to me, wrapped in this handkerchief.

JOHN HILL . I keep a lodging-house, in King's Head-yard, Broad
way, Westminster. Bryan came to my house backwards and forwards, for twelve months—he lodged then with a young woman, at one of the houses I occupy—I have three or four lodging-houses—on a Tuesday or Wednesday, at the latter end of October, he brought a quantity of tea in a dirty coloured handkerchief—I think it was about the 27th or 28th—I did not exactly notice the day—I will swear it was after the Monday—he only asked me to be kind enough to weigh it for him—I did so—it weighed twelve ounces—he took it out of my house into the house he lodged at, in two parcels—it was in one parcel at the time he brought it—he asked me to divide it into two, which I did.

ROBERT GOOSE . I am a policeman. I took Gray into custody, Douglas's mother having given me information on the Sunday morning—I told him what I wanted him for, and that I must search the place, and while I was searching, his sister flew out and locked me in the room—I
went into the next place, and then ran down stairs—I said, "What did your sister do that for, if there is nothing wrong?"—he said "There is only a twopenny thing there that may do me harm."
Bryan's Defence. Douglas and I had frequent quarrels—I never was at Richmond before in my life before my examination—Douglas brought me this tea.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: First Jury, before Mr. Justice Park.

div1.p:
186.
HENRY BROWN was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Jenkin Stradling, on the 29th of August, at St. Paul's, Deptford, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 2l.; 6 seals, value 4l.; and 1 watch chain, value 1s.; his property.

JENKIN STRADLING . I live on my property, in the Vauxhall-road, Pimlico. On the night of the 22nd of August, I was returning from Blackheath to my residence—I got to New-cross about a quarter or ten minutes to ten o'clock—I had drank more than I should have done—when I got near New-cross, I found myself Very ill in the stomach, and sat down on the bank by the side of the road—I found my watch was gone, and my chain, and six gold seals—afterwards I got up from there, and walked on; and met a policeman, named Redwood, whose father I had known very well—I told him of it—I had discovered I had lost my watch, before I met him—I discovered that before ten o'clock—I felt it safe about the turnpike gate, on this side of Deptford—I do not think the bank it above one hundred yards from the turnpike-gate—I felt in my pocket, and found the guard-chain, which was round my neck under my waistcoat, was broken, and the watch gone—I had not felt any body tugging at my watch—I was either knocked down, or pushed down fin the road, I think—I did not feel any body near me—I felt a knock or push when I got up from the bank—it was after that that I found my chain broken—a man pushed me down—that is the person standing there, (the prisoner)—I gave a description of him—it was after that man knocked or pushed me down, that I missed my watch—after that I met the policeman, and told him some
thing—to the best of my recollection, it was the prisoner—I did not know whether I was pushed or knocked down, but the more I have looked at the prisoner these three or four days, I am the more convinced—I got into a hackney coach, and went home without speaking that night—when the witness looked for me that night, I was gone off in the coach—I did not see the prisoner before that night—I have no recollection of drinking with him—he was shown to me the morning after the robbery, and I swore he was the man who was ill using me that night; and I asked him what he had done with my watch and seals—he said he had never seen them—I do not recollect feeling any thing done to my watch or watch chain, at the time I was pushed or knocked down—my watch was in my fob, and the guard was round my neck—that was broken, and I look upon it it was broken with a pair of pinchers—it was a very strong one—I put it under my waistcoat—it was made of strong steel—I do not know what parish the place is in where I received the push—I believe they call it St. Paul's, Deptford—it is in Surrey—I had six gold seals to my watch, and a steel chain—the watch was a silver hunter.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You are a gentleman, living on your means? A. Yes; in the Vauxhall-road, Pimlico—I had been that evening to Blackheath—there was nothing the matter with me when I went

there, which was about three o'clock in the afternoon, I think—I walked to see the tunnel—I was at a public-house at the side of Blackheath—I did not spend the evening with any body, that I recollect—I went from one place to the other—I was at no private house—I must have spent the even
ing at a public-house.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to represent you were so drunk you really forget all about it? A. I confess, that in the first instance I can remem
ber very little of it.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know the Kentish Drover's public-house? A. No—I came to this Court on the 1st of November, when my Lords were on the bench—I did not tell a Mr. Warner on that occasion that I was satisfied the prisoner was not the man, nor that I had every reason to be
lieve that Stone, the witness, was unworthy of belief—Mr. Warner has al
tered his opinion altogether—I have got another solicitor; and if Mr. Warner was subpoenaed here, the prisoner would be found guilty in fire minutes.

COURT. Q. Were you here when all the Judges were here about four weeks ago? A. I was here the day all the Judges were here, I recollect—I never said the prisoner was not the man who robbed me—I am certain I did not—I never said I believed the witness Stone was unworthy of cre
dit—I had no reason to say so.

JOSIAH STONE . I am a gentleman's servant. On the 22nd of August I was in the service of Mr. Halden, at New Cross, near the turnpike—on that night I was coming out of my master's gate, about ten minutes before ten o'clock—I saw two men up against a high wall on the opposite side of the road—I think the road is about twenty yards wide—they were both close together, and did not move on—they were standing up—during the time they were standing against the wall a cart or waggon went by—I did not take particular notice which—after that went by, the young man's hat fell off—one was an old man, and the other a young man—the young man had his back towards me, and he had the old gentleman against the wall for about two minutes—they were standing still, only the young man had his arms round him somewhere about his middle, as I thought—after they had been there about two minutes, or two minutes and a half, the young man's hat went off, and he left go of the old gentleman, and walked away—the footpath is feather-edged off, and the old gentleman walked away about fifteen yards into the road—the young man then felt on the footpath, as if he was feeling for something—he also grappled in the grass on each side the footpath, both by the wall and the other side—he then picked up his hat, and ran after the old gentleman, who had got about fifteen yards down in the middle of the road—he laid hold of him, and flung him down on his back—he had him there about a minute and a half in the middle of the high road—the old gentleman's hat fell off about five yards from him—I was standing at the end of the lane—I had not gone on—I stood my ground—I did not stir a foot—it was fifteen yards from where I stood to where the young man threw the old man down—the young man left the old man down in the road—the old man had gone rather farther down the road—I do not think I was more than fifteen yards off when I saw him thrown down in the road—it was the width of the road—the young man left him, and ran towards me—I was standing at the end of the lane—I could not see his face, but I took the dimensions of his height and his dress while he ran up towards me—I saw he had on a dark coat, a dark waistcoat, and dark trowsers, and he had on a very narrow-brimmed hat—he passed by me—he was running, but not

very quick—a slow run—he went by me down Newcross-lane, the lane leading to Mr. Hardcastle's—it leads down—it is a kind of back carriage way down to Mr. Hardcastle's house, and it leads down to a pathway—it is a narrow cut for foot-passengers—it leads also to a footway either going to the Five Bells, or you can turn to the right—I lost sight of him for about two minutes—I ran to the old gentleman, and asked him what the man had done at him—the gentleman said something, and I immediately ran after the man down the lane—I could see nobody going down the lane—I ran half way down, and thought he had jumped over some palings into a field—I ran back again to the old gentleman, and said, "Has he robbed you of any thing else?"—he said, "I don't know at present;" and while I was speaking to him, I saw a man come from over the field, which was twenty or twenty-five yards off, up the road, over a kind of bank, not a hedge—the man who ran down the lane could very well have returned and come over that bank—I did not see him come over the top of the bank, but I saw him run from the bank into the middle of the high road, across the footpath—I did not see him come over the bank—he came from the bank—he came into the road with his hands under his coat flap, and walked coolly down to the old gentleman and me—I was not making any words, or talking—he said, "What is the matter?"

Q. Who was the young man with his hands under his coat? A. The pri
soner—I said, "This gentleman has just been robbed of his watch"—he said, "Oh, that be d—d, nothing of the kind"—I then said, "He has, for I saw it all"—I said "I will have nothing to do with it," and I bade them good night—I ran up towards Croydon canal bridge to see for a policeman—I did not see any, and I returned back again—I did not see either the pri
soner or the prosecutor—they were gone—I saw the prisoner again about a quarter of an hour after, below the Newcross turnpike-gate, opposite Mr. Hardcastle's gate nearly—it leads up to what I call the front coach-road, further down from London—he was by himself walking along the road—I did not give him in charge—I told the policeman, when I saw him coming down Mr. Hardcastle's coach-road, what had happened—I gave a descrip
tion of it to the policeman, Ledger, of the R division, and he took him in my presence.

Q. You observed the height, figure, and dress of the man; what is your belief as to the prisoner? A. He is the same man by dress that passed me at the end of the lane from the old man, and came up again—he has the same dress, and is the same height, as near as I can guess, but I did not see the young man's face—it might be another man in the same dress—I cannot say.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You said just now you were in the service of a respectable gentleman, named Halden? A. I was at that time—I have left about a month, or rather better—I left him on account of the garden—I believe he discharged me—I am quite sure he did—the place did not exactly suit me—there was another reason—I had been to the George, and had a pint of beer along with a friend, and coming home, master thought I was rather tipsy—I was not discharged for beastly drunkenness, but because I smiled in my master's face—I had had two pints of beer—it was about five o'clock in the evening, half an hour before they dined—I took in the tray, to lay the cloth—master told me to go out of the house be
cause I smiled in his face, and he was angry—he said he thought I was a little in liquor—he said, "Go out of my house"—I said, "Sir, allow me to put on my hat and jacket, and I will go"—my master pushed me about—

I had the front door in my hand, and he came and gave me a push out; not because I was drunk, but because I smiled in his face—I was examined before the magistrate—the young man appeared to be feeling for something, and was grappling the grass at the side—I stated that before the magistrate, and about his picking up his hat—I am certain I said the old man was fif
teen yards down in the middle of the road when the young man overtook him, and that he laid hold of him, and flung him down on his back—the young man had the old man against the wall for about two minutes and a half—I said so before the magistrate, and that he took hold of him round the waist—that the old gentleman's hat flew off five yards from him—that I took the dimensions of his height—that he went away past me at a slow run—that when he asked what was the matter, I said the old gentleman had been robbed; and he replied, "That be d—d," &c.—that he came up, with his hands behind him, as if nothing was the matter: and that I said I would have nothing to do with it.

Q. Do I understand from your evidence when you had this conversation with the young man, after coming up to the assistance of the old one, that you believed him to be the person who robbed the old man? A. I believed him to be the person who passed by me down the lane, and that was the person, by his dress, whom I saw with the old gentleman, and who robbed him, if he was robbed there—after I had the conversation with the person, I went away, and left them together—they were together alone, walking away—my suspicions were not at all excited from what I saw at my mas
ter's gate—I did not know what they were about, until I saw the old man down in the high road—the man ran towards me after flinging him down in the road—I was determined to be sure whether he had robbed him, before I took him, and I went and asked him—I would not take hold of him till I knew from the old gentleman what was the matter.
COURT. Q. Did you not think it proper to stop him? A. It would have been proper, but I thought I would go and see if he had robbed him.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What have you been doing since you left Mr. Halden? A. I am now living with a gentleman named Jones, for the last fortnight—I have been doing very little since I left Mr. Halden—I hare only seen Mr. Stradling twice—I have been to his house twice since I have been out of a situation—I was at Union Hall when he was there—I cannot tell how many times—I saw him twice before the justice—the last time was Thursday, the 28th of August—I think I went to his house about a fort
night ago—I never was there before—I went and asked Ledger, the police
man, the way to his house—I went to tell him I was going to Manchester, as I had got a situation, and I went to Union Hall twice to tell them—I did not inform them I had got Mr. Jones's situation, and they wrote to Man
chester after me—I went last Saturday week to Mr. Jones—he is in the oil trade, I believe—he lives at Goose-green, Peckham—I went to tell the pro
secutor I had some idea of a situation, and I believed I should have it—it was a situation at some office in town—some building—I forget the name of the place—I think that is better than three weeks ago—it is not a fort-night ago since I was there—it was very shortly after the first time I went—I believe it was all in one week that I was there—I recollect now very well that it was.
NOT GUILTY .

188.
WILLIAM SMITH, alias John Peacock
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of November, at Barnes, 1 gelding, value £30, the property of
Stephen Langridge.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Proscution.

SAMUEL OWEN . I am a milkman, and live at Barnes. On Sunday morning the 19th of October, I saw the prisoner at the Red Lion, at Barnes, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning—in consequence of a message I had received, I went to see him there—I said I understood he wanted to turn a horse out—that was the message I had received—my father has fields close by—this horse was in the stable—the prisoner said yes, and he wished to see the field—I took him to the field, which is not twenty yards from the Red Lion—he inquired particularly if the fences were good—I agreed that he should pay 1s. per night—it was a bay mare, with a black mane and tail—he said most likely he should fetch it out on the Tuesday evening following—I went to the same field on Wednesday evening in consequence of a message, and found the prisoner in the field with the horse in his possession—he had caught it—three men were with him—he took the horse out of the field and showed it off to those three men—he did not pay for the keep—my father had suspicion of him—I went into the Red Lion to be paid for the keep, and he was bargaining with those three men for the horse—he said he would pay me in a few minutes, and Chant came up and took him into custody.

JOHN CHANT . I am a constable. I took the prisoner into custody in consequence of information from Owen, on the night of the 22nd of Octo
ber, at the Red Lion, at Barnes—I asked him where he brought the horse from, and what he was—he told me I might find out—he said he had put the horse in a field in the name of William Smith—and he bought it at Eversley fair.
Prisoner. I said I bought it near Cheshar bridge. Witness. He did not—he said he bought it at Eversley fair—he said he himself bought it—Eversley is in Berkshire, forty miles from Barnes.

NATHANIEL LANGRIDGE . I am the prosecutor's son, who lives at Chaldon—my father is a farmer. This horse was turned out about five miles from our house, on the 19th—I had information that it was lost—I had seen it at Mr. Butt's meadow about ten days before, at Willy, near Farnham—I had taken it there to grass—it had been there three months—I saw it be
fore the Magistrate on Monday, the 27th, in possession of the ostler—I have had it in my care ever since—it is the horse I lost—it is worth £30—I found it at Barnes—Chant, the constable, had it put in a stable there.
J. CHANT re-examined. It was the same horse as I got from Owen.

JOHN BUTT . I am a farmer, living at Farnham. I took in a horse to graze, belonging to Stephen Langride, for about three months—I missed it out of the meadow on Saturday night, the 18th of October or early on Sunday morning I had put it in the meadow myself—I saw it there about three o'clock in the afternoon, and missed it on Sunday morning—I saw it again on the 28th of October, in possession of Langridge, who brought it from Barnes.
HERBERT PEARCE . I am a labourer, living at Farnham. I saw the prisoner on the 17th of October, between three and four o'clock, at his sister's, close to where I work, at Farnham.

Prisoner's Defence. I was there on the 17th, 18th, and 19th, in the morning, and three or four days before—I lived at Farnham—I was bred and born there, and was a horse-dealer all my life, and my father before me—I have been in London with my brother, about four months—he and I went to Farnham to see a relation—he gave me money to buy a horse, if I should see it in my journey—I came back on Wednesday following,

and stopped with my relations till Sunday, the 19th—I came away between three and four o'clock in the morning, and got on this side of Ash, when a gentleman's servant overtook me with a pair of horses—I got up and rode as far as Chesham bridge—and between Shepherton and Chesham bridge, I overtook a man with a horse—I asked if he would sell it—he said yes—I asked what he asked—he said twenty guineas—he would not warrant him sound—he said he had bought it at Eversley fair on the Saturday be
fore, of one Smithers—I knew Smithers to be a respectable man, and bought the horse of him for 18l.—he said his name was John Smith, and he lived near Uxbridge—I paid him the money, and came on to Barnes, and put the horse up there—I asked the ostler if he knew where I could turn it out—he said he knew a friend who had grass—and the witness came—I agreed with him for 1s. a night, and turned the horse out—on Wednesday I showed it to three men, and I told the young man I would pay him.

SAMUEL OWEN
re-examined. When I first saw him, the horse was in the stable—nobody here saw him before it got in the stable—he had no saddle nor bridle when I saw it.

JOHN CHANT
re-examined. He gave me the name of William Smith—he said he put the horse in the field into that name—he did not tell me his real name.

HERBERT PEARCE
re-examined. He went by the name of Peacock—his name is not Smith—I know his father was a horse-dealer.

NATHANIEL LANGRIDGE
re-examined. I know his father was a horse-dealer—I never knew him a horse-dealer—he lived with his father—I know he helped his father, but his father is dead; and he has not dealt in horses since, to my knowledge—I do not know how he got his living since his father's death—I believe he left his father before he died.

JAMES BUTT
re-examined. His brother dealt in horses a little while—I do not know whether the prisoner assisted him—I do not think he did—I have bought horses of him, when he was with his father, not since his death, which was about two years ago—I do not know where he lived since his father's death—Eversley is eleven or twelve miles from Farnham.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Life.
Second Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

189.
JOHN DESMOND,
WILLIAM DESMOND,
HANNAH DO
NOVAN ,
JOHANNA MURPHY , and
MARY HURLEY , were in
dicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
John Cole; they were also charged with the like offence on the Coroner's inquisition.

GEORGE COLLINS . I am a labouring man, and live in Union-court. At the time in question I lived in the Maze, and worked for Smith and Sharpe—I did not know John Cole—he was a stranger to me when this happened—I was told his name by the Jury—I did not see his body—I saw him delivered at the hospital—I went part of the way up Deane-street, and helped him to the hospital gates—I was told before the Coroner's inquest, and by his captain, that his name was John Cole.

Q. Did you see him receive any injury? A. On Sunday, the 10th of August, about a quarter past eight o'clock, I saw John Desmond and Dennis Donovan strike the deceased four times, to my certain knowledge; and his son, William Desmond, succeeded him afterwards—Cole was trying to get from them as far as laid in his power, and begged for mercy, but no

mercy was shown him—it happened just by Mr. Smith's door, at the corner of Union-street, Maze, Tooley-street, Borough—I did not see any provocation given by Cole—I saw him surrounded by these people, endeavouring to escape, but he could not; he was overpowered—I did not see him strike any blow at all—when the man was down, and I ran to his assistance, John Desmond kicked him on the left breast, just on his left ribs—he fell from the blows he received from Dennis Donovan, who is not apprehended—Cole begged for mercy—I wished to assist him, but I was in danger of my life; and in assisting him to lift his head up from the flag stones, I was struck three times myself—John Desmond struck him repeated blows, both right and left, and struck him on the left ear—Wil
liam Desmond repeated it, to follow his father's blows; and struck him in any part which laid in his power—I saw him strike him, and he hit him more than two, three, or four times—the deceased kept on his legs at first—he made no resistance; it was out of his power, he was so overpowered—John Desmond kicked him when he was down, and Hannah Donovan scratched and kicked him when he was down—as he was falling, she tore his face and kicked him afterwards—I cannot say what offence he had given to these people—Murphy had nothing to do with that—nor as to what Mary Hurley did—I went to Guy's Hospital gates, and left Cole there—I did not see his corpse—I did not see any of the surgeons who took care of him—I was not at the first coroner's inquest, but I was at the second one—there was a bit of a skirmish, but I did not see Cole strike any blow—he had no friend there but me—they were all round him—he called for mercy, but got none.

Cross-examined by MR. WHALESBY. Q. Were there a great many people in the place when you came up? A. Yes; there was a hundred, I should suppose, when I first came up—there was a very great dis
