shull complain of your having omitted to state any thing about the game till you came to the second examination? A. I never heard any com
plaint.

COURT. Q. It has been in the course of this cross-examination, put to you that this was a bet of yours for 20l., did you put down on the table more than 20l.? A. Yes, a £5 note, and sixteen or seventeen sovereign.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Will you swear you put on the table more than 20l? A. Yes, I will—I did not take any of it up again—I will swear I had as many as sixteen sovereigns in the bag—I had counted it about an hour previously.

THOMAS POCOCK (police-constable F 98.) The prosecutor gave the pri
soner into my custody in the Strand, near the Spotted Dog, as he was with a cart—the prisoner asked me what I wanted him for—I told him a gentleman in the road gave him in charge for felony—he seemed quite surprised" but he went to the station very quietly—I told him it was for robbing a person, named Ireland, of 21l. from his table in the tap-room—I found on him 4l. 14s. 9d.
Witnesses for the Defence.

MICHAEL GRINHAM . I have been acquainted with the prosecutor three or four years—he is in the habit of playing at games for money, sometimes 5l., sometimes 10l., as persons choose to play—I have known him to play frequently, within the last three or four months, and I have played with him myself—he will play for any thing that persons choose—I should say he is an acute man—I was at his beer-shop on the 21st of October—I played with him at whist, from a little after ten, till about two—he played all that time, he was my partner—he lent me 30s. that evening—I owe it him now—the prisoner and Ireland were continually betting on

the odd trick—the prosecutor never refused to bet—he generally proposed to bet—at one time, there was 10l. betted on the odd trick—the prisoner won it, and it was paid—it was laid down on the table—they went on playing for two or three hours after, and the prosecutor still kept betting on the odd trick, as before—he lost, but I do not know how much—it is not true that he produced some money, upon the prisoner saying that he had not got any, and that the prisoner snatched it up, and ran away with it—no such thing occurred—the prisoner did not take up any money, and, go away with it—he was not so anxious to bet as the prosecutor was—there is no truth in what the prosecutor has sworn, that he only played part of a game—that he did not play out—he continued to play till one or two in the morning.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What are you? A. A baker by trade—I kept a shop near him, about seven years—I was a publican, but I am now out of business—I had a little property when I left my house, and I am expecting a situation—when I let my house, I had money sufficient to keep me—I let it to another party for 150l—I let it to a person named Brown—his uncle or father keeps a public-house in the Kent-road—Brown has left the house, and I think he went to Chelmsford—I got about 150l—I cannot tell exactly—I let it for Messrs. Meux—they can tell—I will not swear I got that.

Q. What did you get? A. 136l. 10s. I think—I cannot tell exactly—it is twelve months ago—I might owe some debts—I did owe about 30l—I owed nothing to Meux—I owed my distiller 15l—his name is Mayston—he lives close by Lambeth-walk—I cannot tell where, upon my honour—I owed my ale brewer, Mr. Goding, of Knightsbridge, about 14l—his col
lecting-clerk called on me once a month—I do not know his name, he lived at Vauxhall, but I do not recollect his number—it is close by the turnpike, just in the Wandsworth-road—I never was at his house—I now live at No. 24, John-street, New-road—I have my receipt at home, no doubt.

Q. What time did the prisoner leave this card party? A. I think about two o'clock—we parted good friends—I do not recollect that we shook hands—we were all friendly—there was no complaint on either side—I did not see the bag in which the prosecutor had his money—he paid in sovereigns, and some silver, when the bet was 10l., there was a £5 note I saw—the pro
secutor lost, altogether, about 16l—the prisoner's partner was a person named Shillitoe—he is a cigar merchant—I do not know where he lives—I have known him about a year—I lost about 2l., and paid it—I had about 12s. of my own, and 30s. I borrowed, and have not paid it—it has not been convenient to pay it.

Q. But you have money? A. No—I did not say I have it now—I had it—I do not know exactly how I am living—I am in view of a situation—I am in no business—my property is nearly gone—I pay every body—I have not paid the prosecutor his 30s.—he has not asked me for it—I never saw him till he took me no in Bow-street—he took me for this money—he said I had robbed him, and the Magistrate discharged me—I have not seen Shillitoe since—I do not know where he is.

Q. What day of the week was this? A. On a Tuesday, I think, I am not sure—there had been a great deal of ale drank—we were rather fresh—I might have been rather fresh—I was not tipsy—I went home that night—I did not go home with the prisoner—he lived at Chelsea—I parted with him at Charing-cross—I did not go to the prosecutor's from

that time till I was taken—I had been frequently before, but I had no occasion to go there after—I think it was on the 21st of November—it might have been October—I think it is not so long as September—I am not aware that I said it was the 21st—I cannot tell the month; I did not take notice—I think it was October—I will not swear to the month, nor to the day—I swore to the day in question—I did not know that I was obliged to swear—I think I could swear it was not November.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was Shillitoe an acquaintance of Mr. Ireland's? A. I do not know—I was taken to Marylebone-office, and then to Bow-street—the prosecutor there said that I and the prisoner went away together—Mr. Minshull said, "When you were here before, you sware he went away alone, and now you say they went away together;" and he discharged me—I have staid late at the prosecutor's house before I played there.

COURT. Q. Then on this night, whether October, November, or Septem
ber, there was no quarrel or dispute, or any going away of the prisoner? A. No—he went away about two o'clock—I had been in the habit of going to the house—the amount of the stake was generally 10s. on every odd trick—there was a bet of 10l. between the prisoner and the prose
cutor—that was the first bet—then was no other of 10l.—I did not bet—I stuck to my 10s—the prisoner is a common carrier; he keeps a cart and horse—it was about half-past ten or eleven o'clock—the bet was made, and they played two or three hours after that; I should think, eight or ten games—the prisoner sometimes betted a sovereign with the prosecutor.

JURY. Q. You had no precise sum playing for? A. No—there was a pot of ale a game—there were ten pots of ale drank, or mostly so—the prisoner went out a little before me—I lost about 2l., but I betted on the trick—Ireland plays at cards, and all games.

JOSEPH SHACKLE . I am an officer of Bow-street. I was present when Ireland was first examined on this charge, and I was there on the second examination—on that occasion the Magistrate remonstrated with the prosecutor on bringing him (Grinham) forward, and swearing that he and the prisoner went away together; when, on the first examination, he swore he went away alone; and he discharged Grinham.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was the prisoner asked what he had to say to the charge? A. He was; and he said they were playing a game at whist and he won the money of the man.

(Thomas Egleton, a tailor, of Lawrence-street, Chelsea; Edward Col
ton, a cow-keeper, of Sloane-square; James Edward White, a publican, of London-wall; William Bignal, a coach-master, Tothill-street; and Luke Thomas Flood, Esq., a Magistrate of Middlesex; gave the prisoner a good character.)
GUILTY. Aged 34.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury .
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TILL THE FIFTEENTH OF DECEMBER .
